# C Proofs
## C. 1 Ridge approximations anisotropic Hölder class functions

To rigorously prove the approximation rate of a Hölder function within each box $\Psi_{r} \subseteq[0,1]^{p}$ using ridge functions, we follow a structured approach leveraging classical approximation theory, partic-

![img-9.jpeg](img-9.jpeg)

Figure B3: Time in seconds to simulate one MCMC chains of 2000 iterations each for models used in the Friedman function simulation study.
ularly anisotropic Jackson-type inequalities (see DeVore and Lorentz (1993)) and known results on ridge function approximation. We thus state the local ridge approximation lemma.

Lemma C1. In each subdomain $\Psi_{r} \subseteq[0,1]^{p}$, if the function $f_{0} \in \mathcal{H}_{\lambda}^{A, p}$, then there exists a ridge function approximation

$$
f_{D}^{r}(\boldsymbol{x})=\sum_{l=1}^{D} \beta_{l}^{(r)} \varphi\left(\omega_{l}^{(r) \top} \boldsymbol{x}+b_{l}^{(r)}\right)
$$

such that

$$
\sup _{\boldsymbol{x} \in \Psi_{r}}\left|f_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})-f_{D}^{r}(\boldsymbol{x})\right| \leq C_{r} D^{-\min _{j} \alpha_{r, j} / p}
$$

Proof. For each dimension $j$, we define the partition

$$
0=x_{j, 0}<x_{j, 1}<\cdots<x_{j, N_{j}}=1
$$

where $N_{j}$ is an integer chosen such that $N_{j} \approx D^{1 / p}$. Thus, each sub-interval has length $\Delta_{j}=1 / N_{j}$. We denote the sub-boxes by

$$
B_{\boldsymbol{k}}=\left[x_{1, k_{1}}, x_{1, k_{1}+1}\right] \times \cdots \times\left[x_{p, k_{p}}, x_{p, k_{p}+1}\right], \quad \boldsymbol{k}=\left(k_{1}, \ldots, k_{p}\right)
$$

Following the ideas of piecewise polynomial approximation in Barron (1993) and Pinkus (1997), in each box $B_{\boldsymbol{k}}$, we define $P_{\boldsymbol{k}}(\boldsymbol{x})$ to be the unique multilinear polynomial that matches $f_{0}$ at the $2^{p}$ corners. That is, if $\boldsymbol{v}$ is a corner, then $P_{\boldsymbol{k}}(\boldsymbol{v})=f_{0}(\boldsymbol{v})$. This leads us to define the global piecewise polynomial

$$
P^{r}(\boldsymbol{x}):=\sum_{\boldsymbol{k}}\left[P_{\boldsymbol{k}}(\boldsymbol{x}) \mathbb{1}\left(\boldsymbol{x} \in B_{\boldsymbol{k}}\right)\right]
$$

Again, note that for any $\boldsymbol{x} \in B_{\boldsymbol{k}}$, if we pick a corner $\boldsymbol{v}$, since $P_{\boldsymbol{k}}(\boldsymbol{v})=f_{0}(\boldsymbol{v})$, we have

$$
\left|f_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})-P_{\boldsymbol{k}}(\boldsymbol{x})\right| \leq\left|f_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})-f_{0}(\boldsymbol{v})\right|
$$

But $\|\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{v}\| \leq \max _{j} \Delta_{j}$. Now, in order to upper bound $\left|f_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})-f_{0}(\boldsymbol{v})\right|$, we use the repeated integration argument for a single coordinate following the lines of Elliott (1994). Fix a coordinate $j$. We define a path that changes $\boldsymbol{v}$ to $\boldsymbol{x}$ only in the $j$-th coordinate, leaving other coordinates the same. Concretely, define

$$
\boldsymbol{x}_{j}(t):=\left(v_{1}, \ldots, v_{j-1}, t, v_{j+1}, \ldots, v_{p}\right), t \in\left[\min \left(v_{j}, x_{j}\right), \max \left(v_{j}, x_{j}\right)\right]
$$

So $\boldsymbol{x}_{j}(\cdot)$ is a straight line in the $j$-th coordinate from $v_{j}$ to $x_{j}$, keeping the others fixed at $v_{i}$. Now, define the univariate function $\tilde{f}_{j}(t):=f_{0}\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{j}(t)\right)$. Since $f_{0}$ is $\left\lfloor\alpha_{r, j}\right\rfloor$ times differentiable in $x_{j}$ (holding others fixed), $\tilde{f}_{j}(t)$ is $\left\lfloor\alpha_{r, j}\right\rfloor$ times differentiable in $t$. Thus,

$$
f_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})-f_{0}(\boldsymbol{v})=f_{0}\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{j}\left(x_{j}\right)\right)-f_{0}\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{j}\left(v_{j}\right)\right)=\tilde{f}_{j}\left(x_{j}\right)-\tilde{f}_{j}\left(v_{j}\right)
$$

The repeated integral argument is elaborated below. Let $m_{j}=\left\lfloor\alpha_{r, j}\right\rfloor$ and $\tau_{j}=\left\{\alpha_{r, j}\right\} \equiv \alpha_{r, j}-m_{j}$. Then:

$$
\tilde{f}_{j}\left(x_{j}\right)-\tilde{f}_{j}\left(v_{j}\right)=\int_{v_{j}}^{x_{j}} \tilde{f}_{j}^{\prime}(u) d u
$$

Again, if $m_{j} \geq 2$, we can write,

$$
\tilde{f}_{j}^{\prime}(u)=\tilde{f}_{j}^{\prime}\left(v_{j}\right)+\int_{v_{j}}^{u} \tilde{f}_{j}^{\prime \prime}(t) d t
$$

Then

$$
\int_{v_{j}}^{x_{j}} \tilde{f}_{j}^{\prime}(u) d u=\left(x_{j}-v_{j}\right) \tilde{f}_{j}^{\prime}\left(v_{j}\right)+\int_{v_{j}}^{x_{j}} \int_{v_{j}}^{u} \tilde{f}_{j}^{\prime \prime}(t) d t d u
$$

Proceeding to the $k^{t h}$ derivative, eventually we reach:

$$
\tilde{f}_{j}^{\left(m_{j}-1\right)}(u)=\tilde{f}_{j}^{\left(m_{j}-1\right)}\left(v_{j}\right)+\int_{v_{j}}^{u} \tilde{f}_{j}^{\left(m_{j}\right)}(t) d t
$$

By integrating $m_{j}$ times, we accumulate polynomial factors in $\left(u-v_{j}\right)$ of integer degrees, plus a "final leftover" that depends on $\tilde{f}_{j}^{\left(m_{j}\right)}(\cdot)$. From Definition 1, we have:

$$
\left|\tilde{f}_{j}^{\left(m_{j}\right)}(u)-\tilde{f}_{j}^{\left(m_{j}\right)}\left(v_{j}\right)\right| \leq \lambda\left|u-v_{j}\right|^{\tau_{j}}
$$

Integrating from $v_{j}$ to $x_{j}$ yields a remainder of order $\left(x_{j}-v_{j}\right)^{m_{j}+\tau_{j}}=\left(x_{j}-v_{j}\right)^{\alpha_{r, j}}$. The standard bounding is

$$
\left|\int_{v_{j}}^{x_{j}} \int_{v_{j}}^{u} \tilde{f}_{j}^{\left(m_{j}\right)}(t) d t d u\right| \leq \int_{v_{j}}^{x_{j}} \int_{v_{j}}^{u}\left|\tilde{f}_{j}^{\left(m_{j}\right)}(t)-\tilde{f}_{j}^{\left(m_{j}\right)}\left(v_{j}\right)\right| d t d u \lesssim\left(x_{j}-v_{j}\right)^{m_{j}+\tau_{j}}
$$

Summing all contributions,

$$
\left|\tilde{f}_{j}\left(x_{j}\right)-\tilde{f}_{j}\left(v_{j}\right)\right| \lesssim\left|x_{j}-v_{j}\right|^{\alpha_{r, j}}
$$

We now do this for each coordinate $j=1, \ldots, p$, changing from $v_{j}$ to $x_{j}$. Concretely, define a path in $\mathbb{R}^{p}$ that changes $\boldsymbol{v}$ into $\boldsymbol{x}$ one coordinate at a time. Denote $\boldsymbol{z}_{0}=\boldsymbol{v}, \boldsymbol{z}^{(l+1)}=\boldsymbol{z}^{(l)}+\Delta_{j(l)}$, where

$j(\ell)$ indicates which coordinate is being changed at step $\ell$. Summing the difference in each step, each dimension $j$ contributes a factor $\left(x_{j}-v_{j}\right)^{\alpha_{r, j}}$. We thus obtain:

$$
\left|f_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})-f_{0}(\boldsymbol{v})\right| \lesssim \sum_{j=1}^{p}\left(\Delta_{j}\right)^{\alpha_{r, j}}
$$

This implies that

$$
\sup _{\boldsymbol{x} \in B_{\boldsymbol{k}}}\left|f_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})-P_{\boldsymbol{k}}(\boldsymbol{x})\right| \lesssim \sum_{j=1}^{p} N_{j}^{-\alpha_{r, j}}
$$

Combining the sub-boxes, we have:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sup _{\boldsymbol{x} \in \Psi_{r}}\left|f_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})-P^{r}(\boldsymbol{x})\right| & =\max _{\boldsymbol{k}} \sup _{\boldsymbol{x} \in B_{\boldsymbol{k}}}\left|f_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})-P_{\boldsymbol{k}}(\boldsymbol{x})\right| \\
& \lesssim \sum_{j} N_{j}^{-\alpha_{r, j}} \\
& \leq C D^{-\min _{j} \alpha_{r, j} / p}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $C>0$ is an appropriate constant. Now, following the lines of tensor-product spline construction in Yarotsky (2017), we can encode each polynomial patch $P_{\boldsymbol{k}}$ as a finite linear combination of univariate basis functions, that is,

$$
P_{\boldsymbol{k}}(\boldsymbol{x})=\sum_{k_{1}=0}^{m} \cdots \sum_{k_{p}=0}^{m} c_{k_{1}, \ldots k_{p}} \psi_{k_{1}}\left(x_{1}\right) \cdots \psi_{k_{p}}\left(x_{p}\right)
$$

A standard argument in Yarotsky (2017) and Barron (1993) states that each univariate $\psi_{k_{j}}\left(x_{j}\right)$ can be exactly or approximately encoded as a sum of ridge units $\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{e}_{j}^{\top} \boldsymbol{x}+\boldsymbol{b}\right)$, (i.e. a "ridge" that depends on only the $j^{\text {th }}$ coordinate). Then their product is expanded into a sum of such units. Summing over all the multi-indices $\left(\boldsymbol{k}_{1}, \cdots, \boldsymbol{k}_{p}\right)$ yields a single sum-of-ridge representation. Thus, each local polynomial $P_{\boldsymbol{k}}$ is replace by a sum-of-ridge function $\tilde{P}_{\boldsymbol{k}}$ with at most a constant factor blow-up in the cardinality. Summing across all sub-boxes, we define

$$
f_{D}^{r}(\boldsymbol{x})=\sum_{k}\left[\tilde{P}_{\boldsymbol{k}}(\boldsymbol{x}) \mathbb{1}\left(\boldsymbol{x} \in B_{\boldsymbol{k}}\right)\right] \Longrightarrow\left\|P^{r}-f_{D}^{r}\right\|_{\infty} \leq \epsilon
$$

for any small $\epsilon>0$, if $\varphi$ is suitably universal. One can take $\epsilon \approx 0$ if for instance, $\varphi$ is piecewise polynomial (like ReLU). Now, collating the bounds from Equations (C1) and (C2), we have by the triangle inequality:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|f_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})-f_{D}^{r}(\boldsymbol{x})\right\|_{\infty} & \leq\left\|f_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})-P^{r}(\boldsymbol{x})\right\|_{\infty}+\left\|P^{r}(\boldsymbol{x})-f_{D}^{r}(\boldsymbol{x})\right\|_{\infty} \\
& \leq C D^{-\min _{j} \alpha_{r, j} / p}+\epsilon
\end{aligned}
$$

Choosing $\epsilon \approx D^{-\min _{j} \alpha_{r, j} / p}$ yields the desired local ridge approximation result.
To recall, the goal is to approximate any function $f_{0} \in \mathcal{H}_{\Lambda}^{\mathcal{A}, p}$ globally using a ridge function approximation of the form

$$
\bar{f}(\boldsymbol{x})=\sum_{d=1}^{D^{*}} \beta_{d} \varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\omega}_{d}^{\top} \boldsymbol{x}+b_{d}\right)
$$

where we ensure that $D^{\star} \approx R D$.
Now, we proceed to prove Lemma 1.
Proof of Lemma 1. To approximate $f_{0}$ globally, we define a smooth partition of unity $\left\{\phi_{r}\right\}_{r=1}^{R}$ subordinate to the partition $\left\{\Psi_{r}\right\}$ such that:
(1) $\phi_{r} \in C^{\infty}\left([0,1]^{p}\right)$
(2) $\sum_{r=1}^{R} \phi_{r}(\boldsymbol{x})=1, \forall \boldsymbol{x} \in[0,1]^{p}$
(3) $\phi_{r}:[0,1]^{p} \longrightarrow[0,1]$ is compactly supported on an extended version of $\Psi_{r}$.

The global approximant is constructed as

$$
f_{D}(\boldsymbol{x})=\sum_{r=1}^{R} \phi_{r}(\boldsymbol{x}) f_{D}^{*}(\boldsymbol{x})
$$

Note that we define the smooth partition of unity is obtained by normalizing:

$$
\phi_{r}(\boldsymbol{x})=\frac{\tilde{\rho}_{r}(\boldsymbol{x})}{\sum_{s=1}^{R} \tilde{\rho}_{s}(\boldsymbol{x})}
$$

where the smooth bump functions are defined in Chapter 2 of Lee (2003):

$$
\tilde{\rho}_{r}(\boldsymbol{x})=\exp \left(-\frac{1}{1-\left\|\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{c}_{r}\right\|^{2} / \delta_{r}^{2}}\right), \quad \text { for }\left\|\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{c}_{r}\right\|<\delta_{r}
$$

However, this construction does not guarantee that $f_{D}$ is a ridge function. In that regard, one can directly approximate $\phi_{r}$ or approximate an unnormalized bump function $\tilde{\rho}_{r}$ and then normalize. Either way, the key is that each $\phi_{r}$ can be realized by a finite sum of ridge units up to an arbitrarily small uniform error. To that end, we approximate each bump $\tilde{\rho}_{r}$ by a sum of ridge functions. Since $\tilde{\rho}_{r} \in C^{\infty}$, it is known for many analytic activation functions that we can approximate $\tilde{\rho}_{r}$ uniformly on $[0,1]^{p}$ to an accuracy $\delta$ using $D^{\prime}$ ridge units (Barron, 1993; Pinkus, 1997). That is,

$$
\left\|\tilde{\rho}_{r}-\tilde{\rho}^{\text {ridge }}\right\|_{\infty} \leq \delta_{r}, \text { where } \tilde{\rho}^{\text {ridge }}(\boldsymbol{x})=\sum_{l=1}^{D^{\prime}} \beta_{l}^{(r)} \varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\omega}_{l}^{(r)} \cdot \boldsymbol{x}+b_{l}^{(r)}\right)
$$

Choose $D^{\prime}$ such that $\delta_{r} \sim\left(D^{\prime}\right)^{-\kappa}$ for some $\kappa>0$ depending on the smoothness of $\tilde{\rho}_{r}$.
Thus, we can form the approximate partition of unity $\left\{\widehat{\phi}_{r}\right\}$ by defining

$$
\widehat{\phi}_{r}(\boldsymbol{x})=\frac{\tilde{\rho}_{r}^{\text {ridge }}(\boldsymbol{x})}{\sum_{s=1}^{R} \tilde{\rho}_{s}^{\text {ridge }}(\boldsymbol{x})}
$$

Provided $\sum_{s=1}^{R} \tilde{\rho}_{s}^{\text {ridge }}(\boldsymbol{x}) \geq \gamma>0$ on $[0,1]^{p}$, ensuring positivity, and $\left\{\widehat{\phi}_{r}(\boldsymbol{x})\right\}$ is still a partition of unity.

Now, we write

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\hat{\phi}_{r}(\boldsymbol{x})-\phi_{r}(\boldsymbol{x})\right| & =\left|\frac{\tilde{\rho}_{r}^{\text {ridge }}(\boldsymbol{x})}{\sum_{s} \tilde{\rho}_{s}^{\text {ridge }}(\boldsymbol{x})}-\frac{\tilde{\rho}_{r}(\boldsymbol{x})}{\sum_{s} \tilde{\rho}_{s}(\boldsymbol{x})}\right| \\
& =\left|\frac{\tilde{\rho}_{r}^{\text {ridge }}(\boldsymbol{x}) \sum_{s} \tilde{\rho}_{s}(\boldsymbol{x})-\tilde{\rho}_{r}(\boldsymbol{x}) \sum_{s} \tilde{\rho}_{s}^{\text {ridge }}(\boldsymbol{x})}{\left(\sum_{s} \tilde{\rho}_{s}^{\text {ridge }}(\boldsymbol{x})\right)\left(\sum_{s} \tilde{\rho}_{s}(\boldsymbol{x})\right)}\right|
\end{aligned}
$$

Using triangle inequality on the numerator, since $\left\|\tilde{\rho}_{r}-\tilde{\rho}_{r}^{\text {ridge }}\right\|_{\infty} \leq \delta_{r}$ for each $r$, we get $\left|\tilde{\rho}_{r}(\boldsymbol{x})\right.$ -$\tilde{\rho}_{r}^{\text {ridge }}(\boldsymbol{x}) \mid \leq \delta_{r}$ and similarly for sums over all $s$. Altogether, we obtain:

$$
\left\|\hat{\phi}_{r}-\phi_{r}\right\|_{\infty} \leq C \delta
$$

for some constant $C$ that depends on $\min _{s}\left\|\tilde{\rho}_{s}\right\|_{\infty}$ and $\delta=\max _{r} \delta_{r}$. Hence, each $\hat{\phi}_{r}$ can be made as close to $\phi_{r}$ as we wish by choosing $D^{\prime}$ large enough. Having approximated $\phi_{r}$ by $\tilde{\phi}_{r}$, we define the final global approximation as

$$
\widehat{f}(\boldsymbol{x}):=\sum_{r=1}^{R}\left[\tilde{\phi}_{r}(\boldsymbol{x})\right]\left[f_{D}^{r}(\boldsymbol{x})\right]
$$

where each $f_{D}^{r}$ approximates $f_{0}$ on subdomain $\Psi_{r}$. To see the total error, write:

$$
\left\|f_{0}-\widehat{f}\right\|_{\infty} \leq\left\|f_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})-\sum_{r} \phi_{r}(\boldsymbol{x}) f_{D}^{r}(\boldsymbol{x})\right\|_{\infty}+\left\|\sum_{r} \phi_{r}(\boldsymbol{x}) f_{D}^{r}(\boldsymbol{x})-\sum_{r} \tilde{\phi}_{r}(\boldsymbol{x}) f_{D}^{r}(\boldsymbol{x})\right\|_{\infty}
$$

We call these (I) and (II):
(I) By definition of $\phi_{r}(\boldsymbol{x})$,

$$
f_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})-\sum_{r} \phi_{r}(\boldsymbol{x}) f_{D}^{r}(\boldsymbol{x})=\sum_{r} \phi_{r}(\boldsymbol{x})\left[f_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})-f_{D}^{r}(\boldsymbol{x})\right]
$$

Thus, taking absolute values and using the triangle inequality,

$$
\left|f_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})-\sum_{r} \phi_{r}(\boldsymbol{x}) f_{D}^{r}(\boldsymbol{x})\right| \leq \sum_{r} \phi_{r}(\boldsymbol{x})\left|f_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})-f_{D}^{r}(\boldsymbol{x})\right|
$$

From Lemma C1, each subdomain $\Psi_{r}$ admits

$$
\sup _{\boldsymbol{x} \in \Psi_{r}}\left|f_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})-f_{D}^{r}(\boldsymbol{x})\right| \leq C_{r} D^{-\min _{j}\left\{\alpha_{r, j}\right\} / p}
$$

Hence, for any $\boldsymbol{x} \in \Psi_{r}$, we have $\left|f_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})-f_{D}^{r}(\boldsymbol{x})\right| \leq C_{r} D^{-\min _{j}\left\{\alpha_{r, j}\right\} / p}$. Since $\phi_{r}(\boldsymbol{x}) \leq 1$, we get

$$
\sum_{r} \phi_{r}(\boldsymbol{x})\left|f_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})-f_{D}^{r}(\boldsymbol{x})\right| \leq \max _{1 \leq r \leq R} \sup _{\boldsymbol{x} \in \Psi_{r}}\left|f_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})-f_{D}^{r}(\boldsymbol{x})\right| \leq \max _{r} C_{r} D^{-\min _{j}\left\{\alpha_{r, j}\right\} / p}
$$

Taking the supremum over $\boldsymbol{x} \in[0,1]^{p}$, we conclude

$$
\sup _{\boldsymbol{x} \in[0,1]^{p}}\left|f_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})-\sum_{r} \phi_{r}(\boldsymbol{x}) f_{D}^{r}(\boldsymbol{x})\right| \leq \max _{1 \leq r \leq R}\left\{C_{r}\right\} D^{-\min _{r, j}\left\{\alpha_{r, j}\right\} / p}
$$

Letting $C=\max _{r} C_{r} R^{\min _{r, j} \alpha_{r, j} / p}$, we obtain

$$
\left\|f_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})-\sum_{r} \phi_{r}(\boldsymbol{x}) f_{D}^{r}(\boldsymbol{x})\right\|_{\infty} \leq C D^{\star-\min _{r, j} \alpha_{r, j} / p}
$$

(II) $\left\|\sum_{r}\left[\phi_{r}(\boldsymbol{x})-\widehat{\phi}_{r}(\boldsymbol{x})\right] f_{D}^{r}(\boldsymbol{x})\right\|_{\infty} \leq \sum_{r}\left\|\phi_{r}-\widehat{\phi}_{r}\right\|_{\infty} \sup _{\boldsymbol{x}}\left|f_{D}^{r}(\boldsymbol{x})\right|$. Each $f_{D}^{r}$ is bounded by some constant depending on $\left\|f_{0}\right\|_{\infty}, \lambda$. Then $\left\|\phi_{r}-\widehat{\phi}_{r}\right\|_{\infty} \leq C^{\prime} \delta$ from Equation C3 implies (II) is at most $O(\delta)$.

Hence,

$$
\|f-\widehat{f}\|_{\infty} \leq C D^{\star-\min _{r, j} \alpha_{r, j} / p}+O(\delta)
$$

By choosing $\delta \approx D^{\star-\min _{r, j} \alpha_{r, j} / p}$, the two terms become comparable, giving $\|f-\widehat{f}\|_{\infty} \approx O\left(D^{\star-\min _{r, j} \alpha_{r, j} / p}\right)$.

# C. 2 Proof of Theorem 1 

To establish the contraction rate of the posterior distribution for the piecewise anisotropic Sobolev function estimation, we consider the underlying partition $\chi_{0}^{*}=\left\{\Xi_{1}^{*}, \ldots, \Xi_{R}^{*}\right\}$ for the true function $f_{0}$, which is unknown. To approximate the piecewise functions in each of these spaces $\mathcal{H}_{\chi}^{\boldsymbol{\alpha}_{r}}\left(\chi_{0}^{*}\right)$ for $r=1,2, \ldots, R$, we need to construct tree learners. This requires defining a discrete collection of locations where splits can occur, which Jeong and Ročková (2023) referred to as a "split-net," denoted by $\mathcal{Z}$. Given a split-net $\mathcal{Z}$, a $\mathcal{Z}$-tree partition is a tree-structured partition in which the tree splits only at points in $\mathcal{Z}$. The capacity of the $\mathcal{Z}$-tree partition to detect $\chi_{0}^{*}$ is closely related to the density of the split-net, defined as follows.

Definition 3 (Dense split-net). For any given $c_{n} \geq 0$, a split-net $\mathcal{Z}=\left\{\boldsymbol{z}_{i} \in[0,1]^{p}, i=1,2, \ldots, b_{n}\right\}$ is said to be $\left(\chi_{0}^{*}, c_{n}\right)$-dense if there exists a $\mathcal{Z}$-tree partition $\mathcal{T}=\left\{\Omega_{1}, \ldots, \Omega_{J}\right\}$ of $[0,1]^{p}$ such that $\Upsilon\left(\chi_{0}^{*}, \mathcal{T}\right) \leq c_{n} .^{1}$

Thus, for a good approximation of $\chi_{0}^{*}$, we need $c_{n}$ tending to zero at a suitable rate. Additionally, the split-net should be regular enough to capture the behavior of $f_{0}$ on each box $\Xi_{r}^{*}$. This is taken care of by constructing the anisotropic k-d tree as elaborated in Jeong and Ročková (2023, Definition 9). Each component $\Omega_{r}^{*}$ of the $\mathcal{Z}$-tree partition is subdivided by the anisotropic k-d tree partition with depth $L, \mathcal{T}_{r}^{0}=\left\{\Omega_{r 1}^{0}, \ldots, \Omega_{r 2^{L}}^{0}\right\}$. Our approximating partition $\tilde{\mathcal{T}}$ is constituted by agglomerating all sub-tree partitions $\mathcal{T}_{r}^{0}$, given by

$$
\tilde{\mathcal{T}}=\left\{\Omega_{11}^{0}, \ldots, \Omega_{12^{L}}^{0}, \ldots, \Omega_{R 1}^{0}, \ldots, \Omega_{R 2^{L}}^{0}\right\}
$$

We first show that, under these and four additional technical assumptions ((A4)-(A7)), all functions $\mathcal{H}_{\chi}^{A, p}(\boldsymbol{\Psi})$ can be approximated by a sufficiently deep anisotropic $k-d$ tree (Jeong and Ročková, 2023, Definition 9) that outputs linear combinations of ridge functions. The additional assumptions are stated below:
(A4) The split-net $\mathcal{Z}$ is $\left(\chi_{0}^{*}, c_{n}\right)$-dense, where $c_{n} \lesssim n^{-\left(1+2 a_{2}\right) / 2 a_{1}}(\log n)^{-1 / 2 a_{1}}$.
(A5) The split net is $\left(\Xi_{r}^{*}, \boldsymbol{\alpha}_{r}, L\right)$-regular for every $r=1,2, \ldots, R$, with $2^{L} \asymp\left({ }^{n(\lambda p)^{2}} /(R \log n)\right)^{p /(2 a+p)}$.
(A6) The split net $\mathcal{Z}$ satisfies $\max _{1 \leq j \leq p} \log b_{j}(\mathcal{Z}) \lesssim \log n$.
(A7) $\max _{r} \operatorname{dep}\left(\Omega_{r}^{*}\right) \lesssim \log n$.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{4} \Upsilon$ denotes the Hausdorff divergence between two box partitions.

These assumptions ensure that the boundaries of the underlying box partition can be well detected by the binary tree partitioning rule. In particular, assumptions (A4) and (A6) ensures the split-net is dense enough to approximate the unknown partition's boundaries. Assumption (A5) sets the anisotropic k-d tree depth $L$ so that the partition can achieve the correct approximation rate w.r.t. $\boldsymbol{\alpha}_{r}$. Assumption (A7) caps the maximum depth needed for any sub-box $\Omega_{r}^{*}$ to $\lesssim \log n$, preventing excessively large trees. It is useful to state that throughout this section, we define the class of functions defined on any tree partition $\mathcal{T}$ as $\mathcal{F}_{\mathcal{T}}$.

Lemma C2 (Anisotropic Approximation theory). Assume (A1)-(A7), (P1)-(P4). Then for any $f_{0} \in \mathcal{H}_{\lambda}^{A, p}\left(\boldsymbol{\chi}_{0}^{*}\right)$, there exists an anisotropic $k$-d tree partition $\hat{\mathcal{T}}$ of depth $L$ such that $2^{\hat{L}} \asymp$ $\left({ }^{n(\lambda p)^{2}} /(R \log n)\right)^{p /(2 \bar{\alpha}+p)}$ and $\hat{f}_{0} \in \mathcal{F}_{\mathcal{T}}$ such that

$$
\left\|f_{0}-\hat{f}_{0}\right\|_{\infty} \lesssim \epsilon_{n}:=(\lambda p)^{p /(2 \bar{\alpha}+p)}\left((R \log n) / n\right)^{\bar{\alpha} /(2 \bar{\alpha}+p)}
$$

Proof. Fix $r$ and $k$. For any $\boldsymbol{x} \in \Omega_{r k}^{0}$, we define

$$
\boldsymbol{x}^{*}=\arg \min _{\boldsymbol{z} \in \operatorname{cl}\left(\Omega_{r k}^{0} / \mathbb{E}_{r}^{*}\right)}\|\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{z}\|_{1}
$$

Observe the following string of inequalities:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|f_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})-\hat{f}_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})\right\|_{\infty} & =\left\|f_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})-f_{0}\left(\boldsymbol{x}^{*}\right)+f_{0}\left(\boldsymbol{x}^{*}\right)-\hat{f}_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})\right\|_{\infty} \\
& \leq\left\|f_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})-f_{0}\left(\boldsymbol{x}^{*}\right)\right\|_{\infty}+\left\|f_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})-\hat{f}_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})\right\|_{\infty} \\
& \leq \underbrace{\left\|f_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})-f_{0}\left(\boldsymbol{x}^{*}\right)\right\|_{\infty}}_{\text {(i) }}+\underbrace{\left\|f_{0}\left(\boldsymbol{x}^{*}\right)-f_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})\right\|_{\infty}}_{\text {(ii) }}+\underbrace{\left\|f_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})-\hat{f}_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})\right\|_{\infty}}_{\text {(iii) }}
\end{aligned}
$$

Since we know that $f_{0}$ is $\alpha_{r j}$-Holder continuous in each box, this implies

$$
(i) \leq \lambda p c_{n}^{\min \alpha_{r j}}
$$

Since $\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{x}^{*} \in \Omega_{r k}^{0}$, from the anisotropic tree construction, we have

$$
(i i) \leq \lambda p 2^{-\bar{\alpha} l / p}
$$

following the tree construction elaborated in the proof of Theorem 1 in Jeong and Ročková (2023). Note that if $\left(l_{r 1}, \ldots, l_{r p}\right)^{\top}$ be the counter vector returned by the anisotropic k-d tree construction algorithm, such that $L=\sum_{j=1}^{p} l_{r j}$, for $r=1,2, \ldots, R$, then following the proof technique of Jeong and Ročková (2023), we take $\tilde{l}_{r j}=L \bar{\alpha} / p \alpha_{r j}$, which implies the equalities

$$
\alpha_{r 1} \tilde{l}_{r 1}=\ldots=\alpha_{r p} \tilde{l}_{r p}, \text { and } L=\sum_{j=1}^{p} \tilde{l}_{r j}
$$

Observing that $l_{r j}>\tilde{l}_{r j}-1$, we can claim that the above inequality holds since,

$$
\text { (ii) } \lesssim \lambda \sum_{j=1}^{p} 2^{-\alpha_{r j} l_{r j}} \leq 2 \lambda \sum_{j=1}^{p} 2^{-\alpha_{r j} \tilde{l}_{r j}} \leq 2 \lambda p 2^{-\bar{\alpha} l / p}
$$

Assumptions (A1) - (A4) imply that the Hölder function class can be well approximated by the class of ridge functions.

$$
(i i i)=\left\|f_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})-\hat{f}_{0}(\boldsymbol{x})\right\|_{\infty} \leq C D^{\star-\min _{r, j} \alpha_{r, j} / p}
$$

where $C$ is a constant independent of $f_{0}$. Collating all the bounds, and observing that the upper bound for (iii) is asymptotically constant as $p \rightarrow \infty$, we have

$$
\left\|f_{0}-\hat{f}_{0}\right\|_{\infty} \lesssim \lambda p\left(c_{n}^{\min \alpha_{r j}}+2^{-\alpha L / p}\right) \lesssim \epsilon_{n}
$$

Note that following the lines of Corollary 1 in Jeong and Ročková (2023), if we assume (A2) and (A4), then $c_{n}^{\min _{r, j} \alpha_{r, j}} \lesssim \epsilon_{n} / \lambda p$ proves the final inequality.

Up to this point, we have focused on single tree learners. We now shift our attention to forests for the next sequence of results. We define a tree ensemble $\mathcal{E}=\left\{\mathcal{T}^{1}, \ldots, \mathcal{T}^{\mathcal{T}}\right\}$ and denote the approximating ensemble by $\hat{\mathcal{E}}$, obtained by accumulating all the anisotropic k-d trees. Henceforth, we define $\mathcal{F}_{\mathcal{E}}$ as the set of functions $f_{\mathcal{E}}$ which satisfy:

$$
f_{\mathcal{E}}(\boldsymbol{x})=\sum_{t=1}^{T} \sum_{k=1}^{K_{t}} \beta_{t k} \cdot \varphi\left(\omega_{t k}^{\top} \boldsymbol{x}+b_{t k}\right)
$$

We require the following lemmas to establish our posterior contraction result.

Lemma C3 (Prior concentration of tree sizes.). Let $\hat{\mathcal{T}}$ be the $\mathcal{Z}$-tree partition defined in C4. Under assumptions (A5) and (A6),

$$
\log \Pi(\hat{\mathcal{T}}) \gtrsim-\hat{K} \log n-p \log p
$$

where $\hat{K}$ is the size of the approximating tree partition $\hat{\mathcal{T}}$.
The proof of Lemma C3 follows directly from the proof of Lemma 4 in Jeong and Ročková (2023).
Next, we verify the three conditions in Ghosal and van der Vaart (2007) involving prior concentration and metric entropy with respect to the empirical $L_{2}$-norm norm $\|\cdot\|_{n}$ defined as $\|f\|_{n}^{2}=$ $n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left|f\left(x_{i}\right)\right|^{2}$. These conditions are affirmatively tested in the following lemmas.

Lemma C4 (Prior concentration of tree learners.). Under assumptions (A3) and (P1), for any $C>0$,

$$
-\log \Pi\left(f \in \mathcal{F}_{\hat{\mathcal{E}}}:\left\|f-f_{0, \hat{\mathcal{E}}}\right\|_{n} \leq C \epsilon_{n}\right) \lesssim n \epsilon_{n}^{2}
$$

Proof. Assuming that $|\varphi| \leq C_{\varphi}$, observe that for two different ensembles $\hat{\mathcal{E}}_{1}$ and $\hat{\mathcal{E}}_{2}$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|f_{\hat{\mathcal{E}}_{1}}-f_{\hat{\mathcal{E}}_{2}}\right\|_{\infty} & =\left\|\sum_{t=1}^{T} \sum_{k=1}^{K_{t}} \beta_{t k}^{(1)} \cdot \varphi\left(\omega_{t k}^{(1) \top} \boldsymbol{x}+b_{t k}^{(1)}\right)-\sum_{t=1}^{T} \sum_{k=1}^{K_{t}} \beta_{t k}^{(2)} \cdot \varphi\left(\omega_{t k}^{(2) \top} \boldsymbol{x}+b_{t k}^{(2)}\right)\right\|_{\infty} \\
& \leq\left\|\sum_{t} \sum_{k} \beta_{t k}^{(1)} \cdot\left(\varphi\left(\omega_{t k}^{(1) \top} \boldsymbol{x}+b_{t k}^{(1)}\right)-\varphi\left(\omega_{t k}^{(2) \top} \boldsymbol{x}+b_{t k}^{(2)}\right)\right)+\left(\beta_{k t}^{(1)}-\beta_{k t}^{(2)}\right) \cdot \varphi\left(\omega_{k t}^{(2) \top} \boldsymbol{x}+b_{k t}^{(2)}\right)\right\|_{\infty} \\
& \leq 2 C_{\varphi}\left\|\sum_{t} \sum_{k} \beta_{t k}^{(1)}\right\|_{\infty}+C_{\varphi}\left\|\sum_{t} \sum_{k}\left(\beta_{k t}^{(1)}-\beta_{k t}^{(2)}\right)\right\|_{\infty} \\
& \leq 2 \sqrt{K^{*}} C_{\varphi}\left\|B_{1}\right\|_{2}+C_{\varphi} \sqrt{K^{*}}\left\|B_{1}-B_{2}\right\|_{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $B_{l}$ is defined to be the flattened vector $\left(\beta_{11}^{(l)}, \ldots, \beta_{1, K_{1}}^{(l)}, \ldots, \beta_{T 1}^{(l)}, \ldots, \beta_{T K_{T}}^{(l)}\right)$; where $l=1,2$, each of dimension $\sum_{t=1}^{T} K_{t}=K^{*}$. The last inequality follows by Cauchy-Schwarz on $L_{1}$ norm. Now, define a matrix $M^{K^{*}} \times K^{*}$ such that $M B$ is a product of independent standard normal priors. It is worthwhile to note that:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Pi\left(f \in \mathcal{F}_{\hat{\mathcal{E}}}:| | f-f_{0, \hat{\mathcal{E}}, \hat{B}} \|_{\infty} \leq C \epsilon_{n}\right) & \geq \Pi\left(B \in \mathbb{R}^{K^{*}}:| | B-\hat{B} \|_{2} \leq \frac{C_{1} \epsilon_{n}}{\sqrt{K^{*}}}-2| | \hat{B} \|_{2}\right) \\
& =\Pi\left(B \in \mathbb{R}^{K^{*}}:| | M(B-\hat{B}) \|_{2} \leq \frac{\left\|M^{-1}\right\|_{\text {spec }} C_{1} \epsilon_{n}}{\sqrt{K^{*}}}-2\left\|M^{-1}\right\|_{\text {spec }}| | \hat{B} \|_{2}\right) \\
& \geq 2^{\frac{K^{*}}{2}} e^{-| | M \hat{B} \|_{2}^{2}} \Pi\left(B \in \mathbb{R}^{K^{*}}:| | M B \|_{2} \leq\left\|M^{-1}\right\|_{\text {spec }}\left(\frac{C_{1} \epsilon_{n}}{\sqrt{2 K^{*}}}-\frac{| | \hat{B} \|_{2}}{\sqrt{2}}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Here, spec denotes the spectral norm of a matrix. The last inequality follows from the arguments in Ghosal and van der Vaart (2007, pg. 217). The induced prior for $| | M B \|_{2}^{2} \sim \chi_{K^{*}}^{2}$. As the spectral norm is assumed to be bounded, the quantity

$$
v_{n}=\left(\frac{\epsilon_{n}}{\sqrt{K^{*}}}-2| | \hat{B} \|_{2}\right)\left\|M^{-1}\right\|_{\text {spec }}<\frac{\epsilon_{n}}{\sqrt{K^{*}}}\left\|M^{-1}\right\|_{\text {spec }} \lesssim \epsilon_{n}
$$

Following the same arguments as Jeong and Ročková (2023),

$$
\Pi\left(B \in \mathbb{R}^{K^{*}}:| | M B \|_{2} \leq \frac{C_{1} v_{n}}{\sqrt{2}}\right) \geq \frac{2}{K^{*} 2^{K^{*}} \Gamma\left(\frac{K^{*}}{2}\right)}\left(C_{1} v_{n}\right)^{K^{*}} \exp \left(-C_{1}^{2} \frac{v_{n}^{2}}{4}\right)
$$

The logarithm of the RHS is bounded below by a constant multiple of $-\left(K^{*}+T\right) \log n-v_{n}^{2} \gtrsim-n \epsilon_{n}^{2}$. See that $\exp \left(-| | M \hat{B} \|_{2}^{2}\right)$ is bounded owing to the following two inequalities:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\|\hat{B}\|_{\infty} \leq\left\|f_{0}\right\|_{\infty} \text { (by construction) } \\
\|M \hat{B}\|_{2}^{2} \leq| | M\left\|_{\text {spec }}^{2}\right\| \hat{B} \|_{2}^{2} \leq| | M\left\|_{\text {spec }}^{2} K^{*}\right\| \hat{B} \|_{2 \infty}^{2} \lesssim K^{*} \log n
\end{gathered}
$$

under the assumption (A1).

Lemma C5 (Metric entropy.). Let $\bar{K}_{n} \asymp \frac{n \epsilon_{n}^{2}}{\log n}$ and define the function spaces $\mathcal{F}_{\mathcal{E}, M}^{(1)}=\left\{f \in \mathcal{F}_{\mathcal{E}}:\right.$ $\left.||B||_{\infty} \leq M\right\}$ and

$$
\mathcal{F}_{\bar{K}_{n}, M}:=\bigcup_{K^{t} \leq \bar{K}_{n}} \mathcal{F}_{\mathcal{E}, M}^{(1)}
$$

Then, for any $C>0$,

$$
\log \mathcal{N}\left(\epsilon_{n}, \mathcal{F}_{\bar{K}_{n}, n^{C}}^{(1)},\left\|. .\right|_{n}\right) \lesssim n \epsilon_{n}^{2}
$$

Proof. Observe the following from the arguments provided by Jeong and Ročková (2023), for $\mathscr{E}-$ the collection of all ensembles $\mathcal{E}$ containing partitions of size $K_{t}$ :

$$
N\left(\epsilon_{n}, \mathcal{F}_{\bar{K}_{n}, n^{C}}^{(1)},\left\|. .\right\|_{\infty}\right) \leq \sum_{K^{t} \leq \bar{K}_{n}} \sum_{\mathcal{E} \in \mathscr{E}} N\left(\epsilon_{n}, \mathcal{F}_{\mathcal{E}, n^{C}}^{(1)},\left\|. .\right\|_{\infty}\right)
$$

The next steps can be seen as:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|f_{\check{\mathcal{E}}_{1}}-f_{\check{\mathcal{E}}_{2}}\right\|_{\infty} & =\sup _{\mathbf{x} \in[0,1]^{p}}=\left\|\sum_{t=1}^{T} \sum_{k=1}^{K_{t}} \beta_{t k}^{(1)} \cdot \varphi\left(\omega_{t k}^{(1) \top} \boldsymbol{x}+b_{t k}^{(1)}\right)-\sum_{t=1}^{T} \sum_{k=1}^{K_{t}} \beta_{t k}^{(2)} \cdot \varphi\left(\omega_{t k}^{(2) \top} \boldsymbol{x}+b_{t k}^{(2)}\right)\right\|_{\infty} \\
& \leq 2 K^{*} C_{\varphi}\left\|B_{1}\right\|_{\infty}+K^{*} C_{\varphi}\left\|B_{1}-B_{2}\right\|_{\infty} \text { from Inequality } C 5
\end{aligned}
$$

Observe that $\mathscr{E}=\prod_{t=1}^{T}\left|\mathcal{P}_{K^{t}, \mathcal{Z}}\right| \leq\left|\mathcal{P}_{\bar{K}_{n}, \mathcal{Z}}\right|^{T}$, denoting the cardinality by $\mathcal{P}$. We can argue that

$$
\mathcal{N}\left(\epsilon_{n}, \mathcal{F}_{\bar{K}_{n}, n^{C}}^{(1)},\left\|. .\right\|_{n}\right) \leq\left|\mathcal{P}_{\bar{K}_{n}, \mathcal{Z}}\right|^{T} \bar{K}_{n}^{T} \mathcal{N}\left(\frac{\epsilon_{n}}{T \bar{K}_{n} C_{\omega}},\left\{B \in \mathbb{R}^{T \bar{K}_{n}}:\|B\|_{\infty} \leq n^{C}\right\},\left\|. .\right\|_{\infty}\right)
$$

See that,

$$
\mathcal{N}\left(\frac{\epsilon_{n}}{T \bar{K}_{n}},\left\{\|B\|_{\infty} \leq n^{C}\right\},\|\cdot\|_{\infty}\right) \leq\left(\frac{6 T \bar{K}_{n} K^{*} C_{\omega} n^{C}}{\epsilon_{n}}\right)
$$

This is obtained partially from Jeong and Ročková (2023) that if $\left\|f_{\check{\mathcal{E}}_{1}}-f_{\check{\mathcal{E}}_{2}}\right\|_{\infty} \leq K^{*}\left\|B_{1}-B_{2}\right\|_{\infty}$, then we would have obtained

$$
\mathcal{N}\left(\frac{\epsilon_{n}}{T \bar{K}_{n}},\left\{\|B\|_{\infty} \leq n^{C}\right\},\|\cdot\|_{\infty}\right) \leq\left(\frac{3 T \bar{K}_{n} n^{C}}{\epsilon_{n}}\right)
$$

However, since we have the upper bound involving both $\left\|B_{1}-B_{2}\right\|_{\infty}$ and $\left\|B_{1}\right\|_{\infty}$, the covering number must reflect that. To adjust the covering number, we need to potentially inflate the radius of the covering balls i.e., the radius $\epsilon_{n} / T \bar{K}_{n}$ will effectively become smaller $\epsilon_{n} / T \bar{K}_{n}\left(2 K^{*} C_{\omega}\right)$.

The proof concludes by observing the following inequality:

$$
\left|\mathcal{P}_{\bar{K}_{n}, \mathcal{Z}}\right|^{T} \leq p^{T \bar{K}_{n}+p+1}\left(\max _{j} b_{j}\right)^{T \bar{K}_{n}}
$$

The logarithm of this expression is $\lesssim n \epsilon_{n}^{2}$ under the assumption (A5).
Lemma C6 (Prior mass of sieve). Let $\bar{K}_{n}=\left\lfloor M_{3} n \epsilon_{n}^{2} / \log n\right\rfloor$ and $\mathcal{F}_{\star}=\bigcup_{\mathcal{E}} \mathcal{F}_{\mathcal{E}}$. Then for a sufficiently large $M^{\prime}>0$, Under (P1)-(P3), for any $C>1$ and $C^{\prime}>0$,

$$
\Pi\left(\mathcal{F}_{\star} \backslash \mathcal{F}_{\bar{K}_{n}, n^{C}}^{(1)}\right) \ll e^{-C^{\prime} n \epsilon_{n}^{2}}
$$

where $\mathcal{F}_{\bar{K}_{n}, n^{C}}^{(1)}$ is defined in Lemma C5.

The proof follows directly from Jeong and Ročková (2023, Lemma 7).
The proof of posterior contraction follows by integrating the results of Lemmas C3, C5 and C6 into a single result.

Proof of Theorem 1. Define the KL neighborhood as follows:

$$
B_{n}=\left\{(f, \sigma): \sum_{i=1}^{n} K\left(p_{o, i}, p_{f, \sigma, i}\right) \leq n \epsilon_{n}^{2}, \sum_{i=1}^{n} V\left(p_{0, i}, p_{f, \sigma, i}\right) \leq n \epsilon_{n}^{2}\right\}
$$

where the KL divergence $K\left(p_{1}, p_{2}\right)=\int \log \left(\rho_{1} / \rho_{2}\right) p_{1}$ and the second order variation $V\left(p_{1}, p_{2}\right)=$ $\int\left|\log \left(\rho_{1} / \rho_{2}\right)-K\left(p_{1}, p_{2}\right)\right|^{2} p_{1}$. Jeong and Ročková (2023) calculates:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{i=1}^{n} K\left(p_{0, i}, p_{f, \sigma, i}\right)=\frac{n}{2} \log \left(\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\sigma_{0}^{2}}\right)-\frac{n}{2}\left(1-\frac{\sigma_{0}^{2}}{\sigma^{2}}\right)+\frac{n\left\|f-f_{0}\right\|_{n}^{2}}{2 \sigma^{2}} \\
& \sum_{i=1}^{n} V\left(p_{0, i}, p_{f, \sigma, i}\right)=\frac{n}{2}\left(1-\frac{\sigma_{0}^{2}}{\sigma^{2}}\right)^{2}+\frac{n \sigma_{0}^{2}\left\|f-f_{0}\right\|_{n}^{2}}{\sigma^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

For our approximating ensemble $\hat{\mathcal{E}}$, we have

$$
\Pi\left(f \in \mathcal{F}_{\star}:\left\|f-f_{0}\right\|_{n} \leq C_{1} \epsilon_{n}\right) \geq \Pi(\hat{\mathcal{E}}) \Pi\left(f \in \mathcal{F}_{\hat{\mathcal{E}}}:\left\|f-f_{0}\right\|_{n} \leq C_{1} \epsilon_{n}\right)
$$

Typically, we choose the approximating ensemble $\hat{\mathcal{E}}$ by taking $\hat{\mathcal{T}}^{1}$ as $\hat{\mathcal{T}}$ and $\hat{\mathcal{T}}^{t}, t=2, \ldots, T$ to be root nodes with no splits Jeong and Ročková (2023); Ročková and van der Pas (2019). Lemma C2 ensures that there exists a $\mathcal{Z}$-tree partition $\hat{\mathcal{T}}$ such that $\hat{f}_{0} \in \mathcal{F}_{\hat{\mathcal{T}}}$ such that $\left\|f_{0}-\hat{f}_{0}\right\|_{n} \lesssim \epsilon_{n}$. Lemma C3 implies that

$$
\log \Pi(\hat{\mathcal{E}})=\log \Pi\left(\hat{\mathcal{T}}^{1}\right)+(T-1) \log (1-\nu) \gtrsim-n \epsilon_{n}^{2}
$$

Noting that $\left\|f-f_{0}\right\|_{n} \lesssim\left\|f-\hat{f}_{0}\right\|_{\infty}+\epsilon_{n}$ for some $\hat{f}_{0} \in \mathcal{F}_{\hat{\mathcal{T}}}$, constructed as in Lemma C2. This implies that for some $C_{2}>0$,

$$
\Pi\left(f \in \mathcal{F}_{\hat{\mathcal{E}}}:\left\|f-f_{0}\right\|_{n} \leq C_{1} \epsilon_{n}\right) \geq \Pi\left(f \in \mathcal{F}_{\hat{\mathcal{E}}}: \| f-f_{0, \hat{\mathcal{E}}}\|_{\infty} \leq C_{2} \epsilon_{n}\right)
$$

Thus, Lemma C4 lets us lower bound the prior mass in the KL neighborhood since,

$$
\Pi\left(B_{n}\right) \geq \exp \left(-\bar{c} n \epsilon_{n}^{2}\right)
$$

for a constant $\bar{c}>0$. To verify the metric entropy conditions, for a given $\mathcal{E}$ and $M>0$, we define the function spaces as in Jeong and Ročková (2023), $\mathcal{F}_{\mathcal{E}, M}^{(1)}=\left\{f \in \mathcal{F}_{\mathcal{E}}:\|B\|_{\infty} \leq M\right\}$ and $\mathcal{F}_{\mathcal{E}, M}^{(2)}=\left\{f \in \mathcal{F}_{\mathcal{E}}:\|B\|_{\infty}>M\right\}$, where $B$ denotes the vector of outer weights. For $\bar{K}_{n} \asymp n \epsilon_{n}^{2} / \log n$, we define:

$$
\mathcal{F}_{\bar{K}_{n}, M}^{(l)}:=\bigcup_{\mathcal{E} \in \mathscr{E}, K^{l} \leq \bar{K}_{n}} \mathcal{F}_{\mathcal{E}, M}^{(l)}, l=1,2
$$

We construct the sieve $\Theta_{n}=\mathcal{F}_{\bar{K}_{n}, M}^{(1)} \times\left(n^{-M_{2}}, \exp \left(M_{2} n \epsilon_{n}^{2}\right)\right)$ for large $M_{1}, M_{2}>0$. Lemma C5 verifies the metric entropy condition. Consequently, (P3) and tail bounds of the inverse gamma distributions imply that $\Pi\left(\sigma^{2} \notin\left(n^{-2 M_{2}}, \exp \left(2 M_{2} n \epsilon_{n}^{2}\right)\right) \exp \left(\bar{c}^{\prime} n \epsilon_{n}^{2}\right) \rightarrow 0\right.$. Finally, we can conclude that $\Pi\left(\mathcal{F}_{\star} \backslash \mathcal{F}_{\bar{K}_{n}, n^{C}}^{(1)}\right) \exp \left(\bar{c}^{\prime} n \epsilon_{n}^{2}\right) \rightarrow 0$ by using Lemma C6, verifying all three conditions ensuring posterior contraction.

abstract:
Although it is an extremely effective, easy-to-use, and increasingly popular
tool for nonparametric regression, the Bayesian Additive Regression Trees
(BART) model is limited by the fact that it can only produce discontinuous
output. Initial attempts to overcome this limitation were based on regression
trees that output Gaussian Processes instead of constants. Unfortunately,
implementations of these extensions cannot scale to large datasets. We propose
ridgeBART, an extension of BART built with trees that output linear
combinations of ridge functions (i.e., a composition of an affine
transformation of the inputs and non-linearity); that is, we build a Bayesian
ensemble of localized neural networks with a single hidden layer. We develop a
new MCMC sampler that updates trees in linear time and establish posterior
contraction rates for estimating piecewise anisotropic H\"{o}lder functions and
nearly minimax-optimal rates for estimating isotropic H\"{o}lder functions. We
demonstrate ridgeBART's effectiveness on synthetic data and use it to estimate
the probability that a professional basketball player makes a shot from any
location on the court in a spatially smooth fashion.
